text: hello superpath folks! just wondering if anyone's got any pointers / insights / or relevant links on content naming structures in your project management tools? so we're using google docs + asana kanban boards for month-by-month content pieces. and i'd like for it to be obvious at a glance and easy to find what month a piece was published in, who was responsible for it, and so on. something like "Month: Main Keyword" maybe? or does anyone know a better alternative?

text:
I always recommend keeping a massive spreadsheet of all of your content where you can also log other relevant information. That way, you can use a naming structure that makes sense for things in progress in Google Docs and Asana, and simply add the publication date, writer, editor, etc. next to the URL in your spreadsheet. This makes filtering easy and lets you keep everything in one place.

For Asana, you should be able to filter on team members and then see which tasks they've completed and which ones they're still working on. You can then arrange by due date/publication date to see when something has been published.

For naming the actual piece, I have some clients who work with the main keyword and some who use the slug.

Hope this helps!

elements.text:

That way, you can use a naming structure that makes sense for things in progress in Google Docs and Asana, and simply add the publication date, writer, editor, etc. next to the URL in your spreadsheet. This makes filtering easy and lets you keep everything in one place.

For Asana, you should be able to filter on team members and then see which tasks they've completed and which ones they're still working on. You can then arrange by due date/publication date to see when something has been published.

For naming the actual piece, I have some clients who work with the main keyword and some who use the slug.

Hope this helps!

text:
:bulb:Looking for great ideas! I've been allocated more budget than I know what to do with for content next year w/ the goal of a content "moonshot" - a large one-time investment that will pay dividends in terms of increased organic traffic and subsequent conversions. *Anyone have similar experiences? What did you invest in and why?* 

For context, we've increased our organic site traffic by +30% in 2021 via tried-and-true content strategy (i.e., actually having a strategy for content, including new content and pruning/optimizing old content). We do a fairly standard assortment of blogs, product updates, white papers, etc.., but have not spent a lot of time in video, interactive, or audio formats.

text:
So, I'm going to wear my bias firmly on my sleeve here given that I run a business that does this exactly, but...

What about a kick-ass case study/customer success story done as a video first, and then turned into multiple written/audio assets after the fact?

There are dozens of ways to take one great story and turn it into tons of pieces of content across...

• Onsite: Landing page, lead magnet, Q&A-style blog post, a 'how-to' style piece of content, testimonials for your other pages 
• Email marketing: sent out in a newsletter, shared as part of a nurture sequence, used to rekindle lost leads 
• Video: A short cut for social, a longer cut for your landing pages, audiograms you can embed on social, audio snippets you can embed in the written asset 
• Cold outreach: use your success story/metrics when generating new business, send across a short one-sheet version to spark interest
• In-person meetings/events: Create a leave-behind one-sheet, turn it into a slide deck walking through the win, etc.
• Social media (images, video, audiograms)
Customer success stories are massively versatile and can be used across the entire buyer's journey.
One great interview can become an entire campaign's worth of content. And your competitors can never 'rip off' your piece or recreate it because that story and client are unique to you.

text:
If you're not going that road, the other road I'd go is to invest in some sort of proprietary research.

What is a topic people in your space want data on?

Conduct the market research for it to a statistically significant level, publish the results, get cited about a billion times (more links/SEO), be seen as an authority in the space, repurpose that content across channels.

text:
<@U01MM4EAC69>, here are my starting points for kicking off a research project. I’ve completed these at my last three roles, and the dividends pay off for the next 12 months and beyond:

1. *What kind of statements do we want to authoritatively make in our market or space?* And if make this an iterative projective (annual, quarterly), what data points will show trends? A great way to do this and pitch it successfully to executives/management is creating placeholder statements that would be ideal outcomes from your research.
    ◦  Companies spent XX% more on [your category] technology solutions last year
    ◦ YY% of [your ideal buyer persona] say they wish they had a better solution
    ◦ ZZ% of all [ideal buyer persona] say they experienced [ideal pain point] last year.
    ◦ The average buyer plans to spend $AA on [category] in the next 6 months.
*2. What kind of data do we have access to that can answer these questions?* 
    a. Internal databases 
    b. Surveys and questionnaires
    c. Primary customer research (interviews, etc.)
3.*Do we perform this study/survey/research with in-house expertise or an outside research provider?*
